title: New Onset Seizure
scope: ** Initial evaluation and management of first-time unprovoked seizure or first presentation of seizure activity in adults. Covers immediate stabilization, diagnostic workup to identify etiology, acute treatment, and framework for anti-seizure medication (ASM) initiation. Excludes status epilepticus (see "Status Epilepticus" template), pediatric seizures, febrile seizures, and known epilepsy with breakthrough seizures.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Electrolyte abnormalities (Na, Ca, Mg, glucose), renal/hepatic function for ASM dosing
Illicit drugs (cocaine, amphetamines) and withdrawal states
Elevated if drawn within 10-20 min of event; helps distinguish seizure from non-epileptic event
Hypophosphatemia lowers seizure threshold (especially alcohol withdrawal)
Elevated post-ictal confirms recent seizure; metabolic acidosis screen

Extended Workup.rationale: Thyroid dysfunction can affect seizure threshold
Cardiac ischemia as cause or consequence
Eclampsia; affects imaging and ASM choice
Deficiency can lower threshold; important for women of childbearing potential

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Synthetic drugs, medications not on standard screen
Anti-NMDAR, LGI1, CASPR2, GABA-B if clinical suspicion

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (epilepsy protocol)*
Essential/First-line.timing: Within 24-48h if inpatient; within 2 weeks if outpatient
Essential/First-line.target: Tumor, mesial temporal sclerosis, cortical dysplasia, encephalitis, stroke, vascular malformation

Essential/First-line.timing: Within 24h if possible; ideally within 24-48h of seizure
Essential/First-line.target: Epileptiform discharges (spikes, sharp waves), focal slowing

Extended.timing: If altered mental status persists, suspected non-convulsive status
If MRA unavailable and vascular cause suspected
If embolic stroke suspected as cause
Aspiration risk post-ictal, lung cancer screening if paraneoplastic suspected

Studies.rationale: If clinical suspicion for autoimmune etiology

Acute/Emergent.dosing: 0.1 mg/kg IV (max 4 mg); may repeat once in 5 min
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: RR, O2 sat, BP; have airway equipment ready

Acute/Emergent.dosing: 10 mg IM (if >40 kg) or 0.2 mg/kg IM
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: RR, O2 sat; have airway equipment ready

Acute/Emergent.dosing: 25-50 mL IV if hypoglycemia confirmed or suspected
100-500 mg IV BEFORE glucose if alcohol use suspected
2-4 L NC or non-rebreather as needed
NS or LR bolus if hypotensive; maintenance if euvolemic
0.2 mg IV over 30 sec; may repeat 0.2 mg q1min to max 1 mg
Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Chronic benzodiazepine use; seizure history; tricyclic overdose
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: **CAUTION:** May lower seizure threshold and precipitate seizures; use only if severe respiratory depression unresponsive to supportive care

Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Acute.dosing: 40-60 mg/kg IV (max 4500 mg) over 15 min; OR 1500-3000 mg IV
Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Acute.contraindications: None significant; reduce dose if CrCl <50

Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Acute.dosing: 20 mg PE/kg IV at 150 mg PE/min (max rate)
Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Acute.monitoring: Continuous cardiac monitoring, BP; purple glove syndrome rare with fosphenytoin
Cardiac monitor, BP; give via large vein (tissue necrosis risk)

Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Acute.contraindications: Pregnancy (teratogenic - neural tube defects), hepatic disease, mitochondrial disease, urea cycle disorders
PR prolongation >200 ms, 2nd/3rd degree AV block

Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Mainte.dosing: 500-1500 mg PO/IV BID; start 500 mg BID, may increase by 500 mg/dose weekly; max 3000 mg/day
Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Mainte.monitoring: Behavioral changes (irritability, depression - "Keppra rage"); renal function

Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Mainte.dosing: Start 25 mg daily × 2 weeks; then 50 mg daily × 2 weeks; then 100 mg daily; target 200-400 mg/day in divided doses
Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Mainte.monitoring: Rash (stop if any rash; SJS/TEN risk higher with fast titration or valproate co-therapy)

Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Mainte.dosing: Start 100 mg PO BID; increase by 100 mg/day weekly; target 200-400 mg BID; max 400 mg BID
Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Mainte.contraindications: PR prolongation, 2nd/3rd degree AV block, severe hepatic impairment
Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Mainte.monitoring: ECG at baseline and dose changes; dizziness, diplopia

Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Mainte.dosing: Start 300 mg PO BID; increase by 300-600 mg/day every week; target 1200-2400 mg/day in divided doses
Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Mainte.monitoring: Sodium (hyponatremia in 2-3%); HLA-B*1502 screening in at-risk populations

Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Mainte.dosing: Start 200 mg PO BID; increase by 200 mg/day weekly; target 800-1200 mg/day; max 1600 mg/day
Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Mainte.contraindications: AV block; bone marrow suppression; concurrent MAOIs
Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Mainte.monitoring: CBC, LFTs, sodium at baseline and periodically; HLA-B*1502 screening

Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Mainte.dosing: Start 10-15 mg/kg/day in divided doses; increase by 5-10 mg/kg/week; target 1000-2000 mg/day; max 60 mg/kg/day
Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Mainte.contraindications: Pregnancy (teratogenic); hepatic disease; mitochondrial disease; pancreatitis history
Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Mainte.monitoring: LFTs, ammonia, CBC, platelets at baseline, then q3-6mo; weight gain, hair loss, tremor

Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Mainte.dosing: 300-400 mg daily (extended release) or divided TID (immediate release); adjust by level
Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Mainte.contraindications: Pregnancy (relative - fetal hydantoin syndrome); AV block
Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Mainte.monitoring: Free phenytoin level (target 1-2 μg/mL); total level 10-20 μg/mL; CBC, LFTs; gingival hyperplasia, hirsutism

Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Mainte.dosing: Start 50 mg PO BID; may increase to 100 mg BID; max 200 mg/day
Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Mainte.monitoring: Less behavioral side effects than levetiracetam; somnolence; Schedule C-V

Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Mainte.dosing: Start 100 mg daily; increase by 100 mg every 2 weeks; target 300-400 mg daily; max 600 mg/day
Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Mainte.monitoring: Kidney stones (carbonic anhydrase inhibitor); oligohidrosis (pediatric); metabolic acidosis

Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Mainte.dosing: Start 25 mg BID; increase by 50 mg/day weekly; target 200-400 mg/day in divided doses; max 400 mg/day
Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Mainte.monitoring: Cognitive impairment ("dopamax"); paresthesias; kidney stones; weight loss

Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Mainte.dosing: Start 5-10 mg daily; increase by 5-10 mg weekly; max 40 mg/day in divided doses
Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Mainte.monitoring: Sedation; tolerance may develop; CYP2C19 poor metabolizers need lower dose

Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Mainte.dosing: Start 2 mg qHS; increase by 2 mg weekly; target 8-12 mg qHS; max 12 mg/day
Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Mainte.monitoring: Psychiatric effects (aggression, hostility); dizziness; take at bedtime; Schedule III

Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Mainte.dosing: Start 12.5 mg daily × 2 weeks; titrate slowly per package insert; target 200-400 mg daily
Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Mainte.monitoring: Very slow titration required (DRESS risk); QT shortening; titration pack available

Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Mainte.dosing: Load 15-20 mg/kg IV; maintenance 1-3 mg/kg/day (60-180 mg/day); target level 15-40 μg/mL
Anti-Seizure Medications (ASMs) - Mainte.monitoring: Sedation; cognitive effects; drug interactions (CYP inducer); level monitoring

Symptomatic Treatments.dosing: 650-1000 mg PO/IV q6h PRN; max 3000 mg/day (2000 mg if liver disease)
400-600 mg PO q6-8h PRN; max 2400 mg/day
0.5-2 mg IV/PO PRN; use with caution
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: RR, sedation level; avoid if post-ictal confusion resolving

Symptomatic Treatments.dosing: Start 50 mg daily; increase by 25-50 mg q1-2 weeks; max 200 mg daily
Start 10 mg daily; max 20 mg daily

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Well tolerated; may help with ASM-related sleep disruption

Second-line/Refractory.dosing: Choose complementary mechanism; see maintenance options
For drug-resistant epilepsy (failed 2+ appropriately chosen ASMs)
For drug-resistant epilepsy not surgical candidates

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Fatty acid oxidation disorders; pyruvate carboxylase deficiency

Referrals & Consults.indication: All new onset seizures for evaluation and management
Diagnostic uncertainty, refractory seizures, surgical candidacy
EEG scheduling; continuous EEG if indicated
Structural lesion requiring intervention (tumor, AVM, SDH)
Depression, anxiety post-diagnosis; psychogenic non-epileptic spells suspected
Driving restrictions impact, employment concerns, insurance navigation
If post-ictal weakness, falls, injury from seizure
Characterize seizure type, video-EEG monitoring, pre-surgical evaluation
Return to driving assessment when eligible

Patient Instructions.item: **Return to ED immediately if:** recurrent seizure, prolonged seizure >5 minutes, head injury, persistent confusion, difficulty breathing, or status epilepticus
Do NOT drive until cleared by neurology (driving restrictions per state guidelines; typically require seizure-free interval)
Avoid operating heavy machinery, working at heights, or swimming alone
Do not bathe alone; showers preferred over baths; keep bathroom door unlocked
Inform employer if job involves safety-sensitive duties
Take ASM exactly as prescribed; do NOT stop abruptly (risk of breakthrough seizures or status epilepticus)
Avoid common seizure triggers: sleep deprivation, alcohol, illicit drugs, missed medications
Keep a seizure diary: date, time, duration, description, triggers, post-ictal symptoms
Educate family/coworkers on seizure first aid: stay with person, protect head, do NOT put anything in mouth, time the seizure, call 911 if >5 minutes
Follow up with neurology within 1-2 weeks of discharge
Bring list of all medications (including OTC and supplements) to all appointments - many interact with ASMs
Women: discuss contraception with provider; some ASMs reduce efficacy of hormonal contraception
Report side effects (mood changes, rash, dizziness, cognitive issues) promptly; do NOT stop medication without calling
Avoid flashing/strobe lights if photosensitive seizures suspected

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Sleep hygiene: aim for 7-9 hours nightly; maintain regular sleep schedule
Avoid alcohol (lowers seizure threshold; interacts with ASMs)
Avoid illicit drugs (especially stimulants: cocaine, amphetamines)
Regular moderate exercise (not extreme sleep deprivation from overtraining)
Medication adherence: use pill organizers, phone alarms, refill reminders
Folic acid supplementation 1-4 mg daily for women of childbearing potential (especially if on enzyme-inducing ASMs)
Bone health: vitamin D 1000-2000 IU daily; calcium as needed (enzyme-inducing ASMs affect bone density)
Avoid known personal triggers (flashing lights, certain foods, stress, if identified)
Home safety modifications: pad sharp furniture corners, avoid glass shower doors, use microwave instead of stovetop when alone
Seizure alert devices or apps for those living alone (optional)
Smoking cessation (increases ASM metabolism; general health)

differential.features: Brief (<15 sec), triggered by standing/Valsalva/micturition, rapid recovery, no post-ictal confusion, possible prodrome (lightheaded, tunnel vision)
differential.tests: ECG, orthostatic vitals, tilt table test, echocardiogram

differential.features: Variable/atypical semiology, prolonged duration, preserved awareness with bilateral movements, eye closure, pelvic thrusting, no post-ictal confusion, psychiatric comorbidity
Negative symptoms (weakness, numbness), no LOC, no convulsive activity
Gradual onset, spreading symptoms, headache follows, stereotyped
Diaphoresis, tremor, confusion, rapid glucose corrects symptoms
Palpitations, sudden LOC without warning, rapid recovery
differential.tests: ECG, Holter monitor, event recorder, EP study

differential.features: Isolated anterograde amnesia, repetitive questioning, no convulsive activity
Occur from sleep, specific features (cataplexy with emotion)
Stereotyped, no LOC, suppressible (tics), may have sensory urge
History of substance use, known withdrawal timeline
Gradual onset, diffuse abnormality, asterixis, no discrete seizures

evidence.recommendation: MRI superior to CT for epilepsy evaluation
Levetiracetam non-inferior to phenytoin for acute seizure cessation
Risk of recurrence after first unprovoked seizure ~40-50%
Starting ASM after first seizure reduces recurrence but not long-term remission
Lamotrigine and levetiracetam preferred in women of childbearing potential
Prolactin elevation supports diagnosis of epileptic seizure (if drawn <20 min)
Continuous EEG detects non-convulsive status in altered patients

monitoring.item: Neurologic exam (level of consciousness, focal deficits)
monitoring.frequency: Q1-2h in ED; Q4h inpatient; each visit OPD
monitoring.action: If prolonged post-ictal state: continuous EEG to rule out non-convulsive status
Supplemental O2; airway management; consider flumazenil only if severe

monitoring.frequency: Trough level 5-7 days after initiation or dose change; PRN
monitoring.action: Adjust dose; check free level for phenytoin

monitoring.frequency: Baseline; q3-6 months on valproate, carbamazepine
monitoring.action: Discontinue if hepatotoxicity; hold if transaminases >3× ULN

monitoring.frequency: Baseline; q3-6 months on carbamazepine, valproate
monitoring.action: Discontinue if significant bone marrow suppression
Reduce dose or switch if severe hyponatremia

monitoring.frequency: Within 24-48h of first seizure; repeat if diagnosis unclear
monitoring.action: Adjust treatment if epileptiform activity or non-convulsive seizures

monitoring.frequency: Within 2 weeks of first seizure; sooner if structural cause suspected
monitoring.action: Address structural cause; refer to appropriate specialist

disposition.criteria: Single, self-limited seizure; returned to baseline; no dangerous etiology identified on initial workup; reliable adult supervision for 24h; ASM initiated or deferred with close follow-up; outpatient EEG and MRI arranged; understands return precautions and driving restriction

Prolonged post-ictal period; multiple seizures; new structural lesion requiring monitoring; ASM loading requiring observation; social situation preventing safe discharge; need for inpatient EEG; new focal neurologic deficit

Status epilepticus (current or recent); recurrent seizures despite treatment; need for continuous EEG monitoring; airway compromise; hemodynamic instability; significant aspiration; large structural lesion with mass effect; CNS infection
MRI unavailable; EEG unavailable; neurology not available for consultation; need for neurosurgical intervention unavailable at facility
